text: earlier this month I watched Thai
volunteers
digging into a mangrove swamp on the
Andaman Coast this had been a holding
camp for trafficked migrants there were
rumors of unmarked graves
that they found the remains of a woman
who she was or how she died we still
don't know but we do know a lot more
about the brutal human trade into which
she'd been drawn six months earlier in
the same area we'd filmed a group of
Bangladeshi men right after they'd been
rescued from traffickers they've been
found by local officials half starved
and traumatized in the mangroves we
realized then that a smuggling business
originally built on row hinges fleeing
from Yama was expanding what you saw in
Thailand until very recently was
networks of people smugglers and
traffickers making a tremendous amount
of money paying corrupt local and
national officials to either help her
look the other way and facilitating the
movement of these people into Malaysia
it was a secret trade hidden in the
rubber plantations that cover southern
Thailand a sixteen-year-old Mahindra boy
took us to the jungle camp where he'd
been held with 600 others for his safety
we've concealed his identity he demanded
a huge ransom he said making him phone
his family and when they couldn't pay he
was beaten he showed me where they slept
in the open and where he said he saw
people raped and killed this young woman
also escaped from a different camp when
we spoke to her she was hiding in a safe
house since then she's managed to reach
Malaysia I want to tell everyone back at
home please don't come here if you come
here you will end up in a terrible
situation this is worse than what you
are escaping
they don't even provide food for the
children all they do is torturous if you
are to die I beg you die back home don't
come here
Thailand has known about this trade for
years but done little to stop it we were
allowed to join a military patrol along
the coast where the smugglers land their
victims but they seldom caught anyone we
know that boats have been dumping their
human cargoes right in this area that's
why we're searching these mangrove
swamps the sheer size and forested
nature of this coastline dwarfed the
very limited resources that the Thai
authorities are putting into this
operation what we learnt was that the
business had sucked in ties at all
levels this young man showed us areas
around his village we're holding camps
had been set up among the rubber trees
appalled at the abuses he was hearing
about he started sheltering migrants who
managed to escape on TV the whole
community is involved in this business
everybody knows about the camps it's
because of the money the traffic is
higher everyone they hire people to keep
watching the camps to carry food for the
Rangers they go around all the houses
here hiring people most of those
arriving on Thailand's Shores remained
ignorant of the full horror of the camps
but as I found out with this group of
Rangers
who've been caught as they landed the
ransom they'd have to pay to reach
Malaysia was a big worry how many of you
are worried that your families won't be
able to pay the brokers if you end up
with the traffickers again but as
Mohammed a school teacher from reclined
state told me they felt they had little
choice but to risk the abuses of the
traffickers there my animal Buddhist
monk and government's military they are
they are are arrested as they are beaten
between
we don't have any way to escape our life
the Mahanama government so patent bet a
visiting government minister who is
doling out food and clothing gave me the
chance to ask about the scale of the
people smuggling business in Thailand
Minister would you agree that Thailand
has allowed the trafficking business to
go on for too long and become too big
this government is committed to
enforcing the law against the
traffickers he said for years though
only small-time players were ever
arrested like these guards who were
caught with the Revengers we just met
one by one they were questioned by the
local police chief who tried without
success to find out who they were
working for
it's only now after graves were
discovered in the camps that we've seen
bigger fish reeled in this powerful
businessman from the south was arrested
this week although he maintains his
innocence of any involvement in
trafficking
last year when I began investigating
this trade few tire fischels were doing
much about it man at pian Tong a
district chief on the Andaman Coast was
one he'd rescued several groups from the
traffickers and he ran his own roadblock
to stop them from being transported to
the camps further south back then he was
hopeful he would get more support I
believe the government is taking it
seriously he said there are
investigations now which could lead to
arrests not just the small players but
the big ones as well six months later he
is no longer alone and still the full
measure of official involvement in
trafficking here has yet to be exposed
Jonathan had BBC news southern Thailand
